document.masterDocTitle: Reconsideration of the genera Merogomphus Martin, 1904, and Anisogomphus Selys, 1857, including erection of a new genus, with a new species and discussion of additional specimens from Cambodia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Reconsideration of the genera Merogomphus Martin, 1904, and Anisogomphus Selys, 1857, including erection of a new genus, with a new species and discussion of additional specimens from Cambodia

paragraph.materialsCitation:
The type species of the genus
Merogomphus , M. pavici
ranges in S and E China, Taiwan, Laos, Vietnam and Thailand and has the following synonyms:
Merogomphus paviei
(incorrect subsequent spelling),
Anisogomphus pieli Nav√°s, 1932
,
Merogomphus chui Asahina, 1968
,
Merogomphus lingyinensis Zhou & Wu, 1985 ( Do 2011 )
. It has characteristic lyrate male cerci with a strong lateral tooth. A closely related
M. longistigmus
(original combination and spelling
Indogomphus longistigma
, see above) from Hindustan and
M. vespertinus Chao, 1999
, from Sichuan have similar-shaped cerci ( Fraser 1934 ; Chao 1999 ). This shape strongly resembles that found in the genus
Heliogomphus Laidlaw, 1922 ( Fraser, 1934 )
.
M. femoralis
was described as having the cerci ‚Äúsmall, pointed, rather lyrate, .... and with a microscopic black tooth externally at about the middle of their length‚Äù ( Laidlaw, 1931 ).
Merogomphus vandykei Needham, 1930
also has lyrate cerci but without the spine (Chao 1990).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Two other species,
martini
and
parvus
, currently and traditionally placed to
Merogomphus
are very dissimilar, especially in the shape of the male cerci ( Fig. 1 a‚Äìd).

Fraser (1922a) described
Platygomphus martini Fraser, 1922
from a pair from Shillong (presently Meghalaya State of India )
.
In the same year, Fraser (1922b) described the same species again, from a male from ‚ÄòHasimara Tea Estate‚Äô under another name,
Burmagomphus duarensis Fraser, 1922
. In his later paper Fraser (1925) used the names
martini
and
duarensis
in an interchanging manner, and in the next one he ( Fraser 1926 ) acknowledged that error and confirmed synonymy of the two species, as resulted from unavailability for comparison of the type of
martini
at the time of description of
duarensis
. The species has simple, straight, light-coloured cerci ( Fig. 1 a‚Äìb). It ranges in E India , Upper Myanmar and Yunnan of China (
Fraser 1934
;
Lahiri 1987
; Chao 1990).

Fraser (1925) transferred the species
martini
/
duarensis
(and also
Ophiogomphus cerastis Selys, 1854
, from Nepal and?N. India , misspelled as ‚Äò
cerastes
‚Äô; the actual status and taxonomic position unclear, male genitalia and appendages unknown) into the genus Indogomphus (thus first creating the present artificial state of the genus presently known as
Merogomphus
). He noted: ‚Äúthe anal appendages of
longistigma
and
duarensis
differ widely whilst those of
cerastes
are unknown, but there are a number of other salient and good generic characters which are common to all, such as the length of the hind femora, the peculiarly specialized armature of these limbs and the relative length of the last four abdominal segments, which resemble somewhat those of
Macrogomphus
. These in themselves are of sufficient importance to constitute a well-defined genus‚Äù ( Fraser 1925: 401 ). Then a 19-lines long section ‚ÄúCharacters of the genus‚Äù follows, where the above-mentioned characters were characterised as follows: ‚ÄúAbdomen with the terminal segments prolonged, 8 and 9 of about the equal length, 10 very short; hind femora of great length, extending to apical end of segment 2 and furnished with two rows of very long, very widely sparsed robust spines. Anal appendages variable, lyrate or simple
Gomphus sens . strict.
design.‚Äù.

It is important to stress here that of the mentioned ‚Äúsalient and good generic characters‚Äù, the long, sparsely spined femora are in common with
Anisogomphus
, and the long abdomen is in common at least with some of species of that genus, which was not mentioned by Fraser (1925) at all.

One more species currently attributed to
Merogomphus
and having simple, light-coloured cerci ( Fig. 1 c‚Äìd), as in
M. martini
( Fig. 1 a‚Äìb), came from Sundaland. Kr√ºger (1899) described
Leptogomphus parvus Kr√ºger, 1899
, from a teneral male and a mature female from ‚ÄúSoekaranda‚Äù (presently Sukaranda), Sumatra, comparing it with
Leptogomphus gestroi Selys, 1891
,
L. lansbergei Selys, 1878
,
L. semperi Selys, 1878
, and ‚Äú
Onychogomphus cerastes
‚Äù (sic). Schmidt (1935) transferred
parvus
to the genus
Merogomphus ,
basing on the length and armature of the hind femur as the best common generic characters and a small number of crossveins between the sectors of Arc and the M1-2-M3 bifurcation, as a character distinguishing Merogomphu s from
Leptogomphus
.

Laidlaw (1931: 211‚Äì212) considered
Merogomphus
to contain the species ‚Äú
cerastes
‚Äù,
femoralis
, ‚Äú
longistigma
‚Äù,
martini
, and ‚Äú
paviei
‚Äù but did not mention
parvus ,
which at that time still had not been transferred to that genus. He commented the genus as follows: ‚ÄòI ... am forced to the conclusion that these species are also to be referred to the same genus. Important points of agreement are to be found in the venation, in the colouring, in the great length and the armature of the femora, and in the structure of male anal appendages. Martin‚Äôs definition of the genus is not altogether complete. ... But the accumulation of evidence afforded by a consideration of all the characters is sufficient to lead one to the conclusion stated above. ... Its nearest ally seems to be the genus
Anisogomphus
. Characters which serve this alliance are: the long triangle of the hind wing, the occasional tendency for an irregularity of the spacing out of the cross-nerves between M4 and M3-M2, the length and armature of the femora, and the coloured upper pair of anal appendages of the male‚Äù. Note that here Laidlaw enumerated precisely the common characters of
Merogomphus
and
Anisogomphus
but did not do so for the characters distinguishing them: he pointed where these should be looked for but did not specify which conditions are found in each genus.

At last Fraser (1934) had to compare the genera
Anisogomphus
and
Merogomphus
and to state the following: ‚ÄúThe genus [
Anisogomphus
] closely resembles
Merogomphus
and, except for the characteristic anal appendages, can hardly be separated therefrom. Thus the venation of the wings and the armature of the femora agree, including the stalked character of the discoidal cell of the hind-wing and also the long legs and excessively long widely spaced spines on the hind femora, these latter being most evident in the female‚Äù ( Fraser 1934: 189 ). However, he did not place these genera in the same couplet in his generic key, the structure of which was as follows:

- ‚ÄúSuperior anal appendages longer than branches of inferior appendages, simple and without spines or processes beneath‚Äù‚Äîto
Mesogomphus , Merogomphus
and
Stylogomphus ( Fraser 1934: 159 )
.

So in fact we had only a formal opposition of the ventral spine to the lateral one or none. Chao (1990: 456) adopted Fraser‚Äôs distinction of
Anisogomphus
and
Merogomphus
and at last placed them in the same key couplet, as follows:

‚ÄúSuperior anal appendages with ventral black protuberance or big tooth................
Anisogomphus
; - Superior anal appendages without ventral black protuberance or tooth..................
Merogomphus
‚Äù

This key, however, paid no attention to the absence of any ‚Äúprotuberance or big tooth‚Äù in one species placed to
Anisogomphus
,
A. koxingai Chao, 1954
( Fig. 1 e‚Äìf). This resulted in a long-lasting confusion discussed in detail in the next section.

The species
Gomphus torpens Needham, 1930
, from Sichuan was transferred to
Merogomphus
by its author ( Needham 1941 ); it is so far known by females only, and
M. vespertinus
may in fact be its junior synonym.

Merogomphus chaoi Yang et Davies, 1993
, described from Yunnan is strongly dissimilar to other species described in
Merogomphus
up to that time ( Yang & Davies 1993 ): it is large (hind wing 35‚Äì39 mm , abdomen 41‚Äì 44 mm ), has entirely dark appendages, simple cerci ending with a spine and very large and broad, strongly laterally protruding branches of the epiproct. Most probably it was attributed to
Merogomphus
for the formal reason of the simple cerci without any processes. In fact it is no doubt a junior synonym of
Anisogomphus pinratani H√§m√§l√§inen, 1991
, described from the neighbouring North Thailand ( H√§m√§l√§inen 1991 ). All detail of both sexes coincide except a small central occipital swelling present in the female of
A. pinratani
but seemingly absent in the female of
M. chaoi
, but it is unclear at which angle of view it was drawn in the latter ( Yang & Davies 1993: fig. 11 ). So
M. chaoi Yang & Davies, 1993
=
Anisogomphus pinratani H√§m√§l√§inen, 1991
, syn. n.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Diagnostic details of males of some
Euthygomphus
spp. as illustrated in literature: a‚Äìh‚Äîanal appendages; i‚Äìj,l‚Äì m,o‚Äîdistal part of penis (vesica spermalis); k,n‚Äîsecondary genitalia; a‚Äìb,i‚Äìj‚Äî
E. martini
(therein considered as
Merogomphus martini
): a‚Äîafter Fraser (1934: fig. 95b); i‚Äîafter Fraser (1940: plate 3.3); b,j‚Äîafter Lahiri (1987: fig. 364‚Äì 365,314‚Äì315); c‚Äìd,k‚Äî
E. parvus
(as
Merogomphus parvus
): c,k‚Äîfrom South Sumatra, Lampoeng residency, Giesting near Talang Padang, Wai Teboe River after Lieftinck (1941: plate 13, fig. 3‚Äì5); d‚Äîfrom Malay Peninsula, Central Perak, Sungai Plus, near Lasah after Lieftinck (1964: fig. 46); e‚Äìf,l‚Äìm,p‚Äìq‚Äî
E. koxingai
(as
Anisogomphus koxingai
): e,l,p‚Äîthe holotype, after Chao (1954: fig. 293‚Äì297); f,m,q‚Äîfrom China, Guandong after Wilson & Xu (2009: fig. 1e‚Äìg); g,n‚Äî
E. fujianensis
, the holotype of
Anisogomphus fujianensis
, after Zhou & Wu (1992: fig. 16‚Äì18); h,o,r‚Äî
A. chaoi
, the holotype of
Anisogomphus chaoi
, after Liu (1991: fig. 3‚Äì8). Not to scale; i,b,k mirrored.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The name
chaoi Yang et Davies, 1993
, originally proposed in the combination
Merogomphus chaoi
, becomes a secondary junior homonym of
Anisogomphus chaoi Liu, 1991
but as soon as it is invalid as a junior synonym, no replacement name is needed for it because of the taxonomic system proposed in this paper.

Merogomhus tamdaoensis Karube, 2001
, was described from North Vietnam as close to
M. chaoi
(that is to
A. pinratani
), hence placed to the same genus. It differs by being even larger (hind wing 46‚Äì50 mm , abdomen 50‚Äì56 mm ) and having the female vulvar scale incision deep but narrow versus short and triangular in
A. pinratani
. In his later paper, Karube (2014) acknowledged relatedness of
A. pinratani , M. chaoi
and
M. tamdaoensis
and stressed the differences of the last from the other two but not of the first from the second. Anyway, neither
Merogomphus chaoi
nor
Merogomphus tamdaoensis
in fact belong to
Merogomphus
in any sense. While the former is a junior synonym, a new combination is proposed for the latter:
